title-group.article-title: Immune cell death on silicone surfaces drives biofilm formation

contrib-group.aff: 1Department of Bioengineering, https://ror.org/04dese585Indian Institute of Science, Bengaluru, India - 560012

license.license-p: This work is licensed under a CC BY-NC 4.0 International license.

abstract.p: Silicone venous catheters are one of the most used healthcare devices worldwide. Nevertheless, they are associated with a high risk of infections, largely due to biofilm formation on catheter surfaces. Silicone is not inherently prone to bacterial adhesion; therefore, it is unclear as to what drives catheter infection and consequent biofilm formation. Previously it has been shown that circulating immune cells, including neutrophils and monocytes may adhere onto and die by apoptosis on silicone surfaces. This study investigates how immune cell death on silicone surfaces contributes to bacterial biofilm formation. The results show that neutrophil apoptosis on silicone surfaces significantly increases biofilm formation. Also, components of dead neutrophils were sufficient to cause increased biofilm formation. Further, silicone surfaces modified with a hyaluronic acid/polyarginine (HA/PA) coating reduce immune cell attachment and consequently biofilm formation. These findings suggest that to prevent catheter infection and biofilm formation, in addition to preventing bacterial attachment, it is necessary to minimize immune cell death on the catheter surface.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Venous catheters, particularly silicone-based ones, are indispensable in modern healthcare, facilitating vital functions such as the administration of intravenous medication and sampling of blood. Despite their widespread use, venous catheters pose a significant risk of infections. For example, central venous catheters have been linked to bloodstream infections, which constitute a leading cause of morbidity and mortality among hospitalized patients, with mortality rates ranging from 12% to 40% 1–3.

The most common microbial pathogens associated with venous catheter related infections are gram-negative bacilli such as Escherichia coli and Pseudomonas aeruginosa and the grampositive Staphylococcus species 4,5. These microorganisms possess virulence factors that facilitate adherence to catheter surfaces and biofilm formation, perpetuating the risk of infection. However, silicone, the material used to make the catheter tubing, is not known to promote bacterial adherence or biofilm formation 6,7. Hence, the question that remains to be answered is what facilitates the adhesion of bacteria onto silicone-based catheters that results in biofilm formation.

Silicone surfaces are known to affect neutrophil function, chemotaxis and promote death of these cells 8–12. Additionally, recent investigations have revealed that exposure to silicone-based materials can induce alterations in the activation, cytokine production, and phagocytic capacity of monocytes and macrophages 13–16. These studies led us to hypothesize that innate immune cell alterations and death on silicone catheter surfaces promotes bacterial biofilm formation. Herein, we demonstrate that the attachment of innate immune cells, such as neutrophils and monocytes, on silicone surfaces promotes bacterial biofilm formation. Specifically, we show that death of neutrophils on the surface is a driver of biofilms. Finally, we demonstrate that a hyaluronic acid/polyarginine (HA/PA) surface coating reduces cell attachment onto the silicone surface, resulting in lower bacterial biofilm formation.

sec.title: Cell Lines
sec.p: HL-60 cells (American Type Culture Collection (ATCC), CCL-240), a neutrophil-like cell line, were cultured in Iscove’s modified Dulbecco’s medium (IMDM [Merck, USA]) supplemented with 20% foetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% antibiotic-antimycotic solution (Thermo-fisher Scientific, USA) in 25 cm2 or 75 cm2 cell culture flasks as required. They were passaged every three days and used between the 15th and 25th passages. THP-1 cells (ATCC TIB-202), a monocyte cell line, were cultured in RPMI-1640 (Gibco, USA) media supplemented with 10% FBS, 0.05 mM β-mercaptoethanol and 1% antibiotic-antimycotic solution in 25 cm2 or 75 cm2 cell culture flasks as required. They were passaged every three days and used between the 15th and 25th passages.

sec.title: Immune cell surveillance experiments
sec.p: At least five days prior to performing experiments, 5 mL polystyrene (PS) test tubes were coated with food grade silicone (DOWSIL 734 flowable sealant, Dow Corning, USA) on the inside and allowed to cure at room temperature for 48 hours. Once completely cured, they were thoroughly washed using deionized water (obtained from a Millipore MilliQ water filtration system).

On the day of the experiment, first, 5 mL PS tubes (used as controls) and silicone coated tubes (silicone tubes) were sterilised under ultraviolet light for half an hour and then washed with 3 mL of 100% ethanol followed by deionized water. Following this, to mimic in vivo conditions, 2 mL of 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA) in deionized water was added to the tubes which were allowed to spin in a rotor placed inside a 37 °C incubator for 45 minutes. Post coating, BSA solution was removed from the tubes and 2 mL of phosphate buffer saline (PBS), or IMDM/RPMI media supplemented with FBS (Complete media [CM]), or 1 million HL-60/THP-1 cells in IMDM/RPMI media supplemented with FBS was added to three different PS or silicone tubes.

The PS tubes served as a material control to compare against silicone. The silicone-PBS tube served as a liquid control, while the silicone-CM tube served as the serum protein control. These tubes were allowed to spin in a rotor placed inside a 37 °C incubator for 2/8/24 hours. After 2/8/24 hours, cell number in PS-cells and silicone-cells tubes was recorded following which the liquid in all the tubes was discarded. At this point, 2 mL of Luria-Bertani/tryptic soy broth and 20 μL of a 10 h liquid culture of E. coli MG1655/S. aureus USA-300/P. aeruginosa PA-14 (~106 bacteria) was added to each of the tubes and then the tubes were again allowed to spin in a rotor placed inside a 37 °C incubator for 48 hours. After 48 hours, the number of viable planktonic bacteria in each of the tubes was measured as colony forming units (CFUs) while the amount of biofilm formed on the inside surfaces of the tubes was quantified using a crystal violet assay.
Separately, to assess whether dead cells contribute to biofilm formation, HL-60 cells were lysed using 0.1% Triton X-100 prior to the 8 h incubation in PS/silicone tubes.

sec.title: Polymorphonuclear leucocyte (PMNL) and peripheral blood mononuclear cell (PBMC) isolation from healthy volunteer blood
sec.p: Ethics Statement: Research involving human samples was performed in accordance with protocols that received approval from the Indian Institute of Science’s human ethics committee (approval numbers IHEC No: 19-14012020 and IHEC No: 04/05042024), and following obtaining informed consent from volunteer donors.

On the day of the experiment, 3 mL of healthy volunteer blood was drawn and immediately transferred to EDTA-coated tubes. 2 mL was added dropwise to the walls of a 15 mL falcon tube containing 3 mL (one and a half blood volume) Histopaque-1077 (Sigma) held at 60° to the ground. The falcon was centrifuged at 500 rcf for 20 min at room temperature in the absence of braking to stop the centrifugation, which enabled separation of blood cells into different layers based on their density. The plasma layer appears at the very top, with a thin layer of PBMCs (buffy coat) between the plasma and Histopaque layer, followed by a pellet containing the PMNLs and RBCs. The buffy coat and bottom layer containing PMNLs and RBC were transferred to two different 15 mL tubes. Human RBC lysis buffer (150 mM NH4Cl, 10mM NaHCO3, 1.2 mM EDTA) was added to each tube (1 mL to the tube containing PBMCs, and 10 mL [1:10 ratio] to the tube containing PMNLs) and allowed to rest for 20 min at room temperature for the lysis to occur. The tubes were spun at 500 rcf for 5 min at 4 °C. The cells were then resuspended in Dulbecco’s Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM, Thermo-Fisher Scientific) supplemented with 10% FBS and counted. One million cells (PMNLs or PBMCs) in two mL complete medium were used in immune cell surveillance experiments. For whole blood, 1 mL of blood diluted with 4% sodium citrate was used.

sec.title: Crystal violet assay
sec.p: To quantify the amount of biofilm formed on the inner surfaces of the PS and silicone tubes, crystal violet staining was used. First, 1 mL of 0.25% crystal violet solution was added to each tube to stain the biofilms. Even staining was achieved by placing the tubes containing crystal violet solution on a rotor for 30 min. Next, the tubes were thoroughly washed with deionized water to get rid of the excess crystal violet stain and allowed to air dry. Later, 1 mL of 33% glacial acetic acid was added to the tubes, which were then placed on a rotor for 30 min for de-staining to occur. The absorbance of the de-stained solution was obtained at 590 nm as a measure of the biofilm formed on the surface.

sec.title: Colony forming unit measurement
sec.p: To obtain an estimate of the number of viable planktonic bacteria in each of the tubes, 100 μL of the culture was serially diluted in PBS eight times (1:10 dilution) and the last two dilutions plated on LB-agar or TSB-agar plates as appropriate. The plates were placed at 37 °C for 12 hours to allow colonies to form. CFUs were counted for both dilutions, and the mean was used as the final measurement of the number of bacteria in the tubes.

sec.title: Scanning electron microscopy
sec.p: At the end of the 48-hour incubation with bacteria, the liquids inside the tubes were discarded and the tubes were washed once with deionized water. Biofilms on the surface were fixed using a 1:1 solution of 10% glutaraldehyde and 10% formaldehyde. In short, 1 mL of each solution was added to each tube, and then spun on a rotor overnight at RT. Following this step, the tube was cut into small pieces and mounted on Aluminium stubs using carbon tape. The prepared samples were desiccated for 24 hours before being sputtered with gold using a BAL-TEC SCD 005 (BAL-TEC, USA) sputter coater and imaged on JEOL SEM IT 300 (JEOL, Japan).

sec.title: Assessment of cell death mechanism post silicone exposure
sec.p: As described previously, silicone tubes were subject to sterilisation, washing and coating with 1% BSA. Next, one million HL-60 cells were seeded into a PS well plate for establishing control measurements (untreated cells serving as negative control, and positive controls for early [+50 μM H2O2] and late [+31.8 mM H2O2] stage apoptosis) and a silicone tube as the experimental condition. The silicone tube was placed in a rotor spinning inside a 37 °C incubator for 8 hours. The well plate containing control samples was placed in the same incubator. After 8 hours the cells were washed with PBS and stained with Annexin V (5% in Annexin V binding buffer [10 mM HEPES, 150 mM NaCl, 2.5 mM CaCl2 in PBS) and 2 μg mL-1 propidium iodide (PI) while maintaining appropriate unstained and single-color controls. Samples were analysed on a flow cytometer (BD FACSCelesta™ [Becton Dickinson, USA]). Flow cytometry data were analysed using FCSExpress 7.20.0023 (DeNovo Software, USA).

sec.title: Surface modification of silicone
sec.p: The following materials were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich: (3-Glycidyloxypropyl)trimethoxysilane (GPTMS), O-(2-Aminoethyl)polyethylene glycol (Mw 3,000) (PEG-NH2), hyaluronic acid (Mw 25,000), and poly-L-arginine hydrochloride (Mw 5,000-15,000).

PEG coating of silicone was adapted from Zhang et al 17. Cured silicone-tubes were first washed with 100% ethanol. To make the silicone surface reactive with -OH groups, the tubes were exposed to air plasma using a plasma cleaner (PDC-32G-2, Harrick Plasma, USA) for 3 min and dipped in 100% ethanol for 15 min. Following this step, the silicone surface was silanised with 2% GPTMS in ethanol by adding the same into the tube and allowing it to react for 30 min. The tubes were then baked in an oven at 80 °C for 30 min. Attenuated total reflectance-Fourier transform infrared (ATR-FTIR) spectroscopy was used to confirm GPTMS coating on silicone.

After GPTMS attachment on the silicone surface, the tubes were washed with MilliQ water before adding 2% PEG-NH2 in 100 mM NaOH into the tubes and allowed to react for 12 h in a desiccator at RT. First GPTMS coating and then PEG-NH2 attachment on the silicone surface was confirmed by ATR-FTIR spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS).

sec.title: Hyaluronic acid/Polyarginine (HA/PA) coating of silicone tubes
sec.p: HA/PA coating of silicone was adapted from Mutschler et al 18. Cured silicone tubes were washed with 100% ethanol and milli-Q water before beginning the coating process. Hyaluronic acid and PA were dissolved at a concentration of 0.5 mg mL-1 in a buffer containing 150 mM NaCl and 10 mM Tris pH 7.4 (wash buffer). The cured silicone tubes were filled to the brim with PA solution, subject to sonication for 10 minutes, followed by 5 minutes in wash buffer and then 10 minutes in HA solution with sonication. This process was repeated 24 times. The HA/PA dip coated tubes were characterised using ATR-FTIR and XPS for confirmation of the coating.

sec.title: Statistical analyses
sec.p: All statistical analyses including one-way ANOVA and Tukey’s multiple comparisons tests were performed in GraphPad Prism 8.

sec.title: Innate immune cell surveillance of silicone surfaces leads to greater biofilm formation
sec.p: Following catheter insertion, proteins will adhere on to its surface and circulating white blood cells are likely to interact with the surface. A previous study demonstrated that blood cells interact with and undergo apoptosis on silicone surfaces 9. Based on this information, we hypothesized that innate immune cell surveillance of and death on silicone catheter surfaces makes it conducive for bacteria and other pathogens to attach and form biofilms. To test this hypothesis, innate immune cell surveillance experiments using HL-60 and THP-1 cell lines were performed.

Silicone surfaces are not conducive for bacterial growth, and we observe the same in our control studies in which the surface was treated with phosphate buffered saline (PBS) followed by bacterial exposure (figure 1a). Exposure of the silicone surface to cell culture media containing serum proteins also did not result in a significant increase in bacterial attachment and biofilm formation. In contrast, we observed that surveillance of the silicone surface by THP-1 or HL-60 cells for 8 or 24 hours results in increased E. coli-based biofilm formation as measured using a crystal violet assay (figure 1a). Confirming the crystal violet quantification data are representative scanning electron micrographs (figure 1b and supplementary figure 1) that show biofilms on silicone surfaces after they have been exposed to cells. The increase in biofilm formation post-immune cell surveillance occurred on polystyrene surfaces (used as a material control) too but was more apparent on the silicone surfaces.

Counting the immune cells post their surveillance of the surfaces revealed a loss in cell number (supplementary figure 2A) suggestive of either cell attachment to the material surface or death due to interaction, or both. The planktonic bacterial counts (colony forming units of E. coli) after 48 hours of incubation in the tubes revealed no differences in total numbers (supplementary figure 2B) demonstrating that the bacteria did not grow more in the tubes that had been surveyed by immune cells.

To confirm that the findings were not due to the use of cell-lines, the same experiment was performed using whole blood, polymorphonuclear leucocytes (PMNLs) and peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) obtained from apparently healthy human volunteers. PMNL and whole blood surveillance of the silicone surface resulted in higher biofilm formation on the surface post infection (figure 2a, 2b). However, PBMC surveillance of the surface did not follow the trend. These differences may be due to the differences in attachment or death of the neutrophils versus other immune cells on the surface.

To determine if the increased biofilm formation on silicone surface post-immune cell surveillance was independent of the type of bacteria, we performed the same experiments with P. aeruginosa and S. aureus. Increased biofilm formation was observed when the surfaces were exposed to both these bacteria using the same assays (figure 3a, 3b, and supplementary figure 4).

As cell numbers reduce after exposure to silicone surfaces, and the surfaces surveyed by neutrophils have a significantly higher biofilm formation, we conjectured that neutrophil death promotes bacterial biofilm formation.

sec.title: Neutrophil death promotes bacterial biofilm formation
sec.p: Next, we sought to determine if neutrophils were dying following interaction with the silicone surface, and if this could be a mechanism for bacterial biofilm formation. We observe that following exposure to silicone surfaces, HL-60 cells undergo apoptotic cell death. Using Annexin V/PI staining and flow cytometry, we determined that about 50% of the cells were either in early or late stages of apoptosis following exposure to silicone surfaces (figure 4a). As a further confirmation that cell death was driving the biofilm formation, we first lysed the HL-60 cells, and incubated the lysed components with the silicone surfaces. After such an exposure, bacteria were added to these surfaces, and we observed that the lysed cell components were indeed sufficient to promote bacterial biofilm formation on silicone surfaces (figure 4b).

sec.title: Silicone surface modification to prevent catheter infection
sec.p: Microbial attachment on bare silicone surfaces is known to be negligible. However, our data suggests that microorganisms form biofilms on these surfaces due to prior immune cell attachment and death. Hence, we hypothesized that to minimize silicone-catheter infection and biofilm formation, it is imperative that innate immune cell attachment and death is reduced.

We first tested polyethylene glycol (PEG); a polymer well known for reducing immune cell interaction with surfaces. PEG4000 was coated onto silicone surfaces (supplementary figure 5), and these modified surfaces were used in the immune surveillance experiments. However, we found that PEG did not significantly reduce immune cell attachment or death (supplementary figure 6A). Further, it did not reduce biofilm formation either based on crystal violet staining of the tubes (supplementary figure 6B).

Mutschler et al. showed that an alternating electrolyte coating of HA and PA was successful in preventing bacterial attachment as well as in killing any bacteria that adhered 18. Hence, we assessed its effects on innate immune cell attachment as well. Successful coating of HA/PA on silicone tubes was confirmed using ATR-FTIR and XPS (supplementary figure 7). The HA/PA coated silicone surfaces had increased number of live immune cells following surveillance suggesting that the coating reduces neutrophil cell death (Figure 5a). Subsequently, we also observed that the bacterial (E. coli) biofilm formation was lower on the coated as compared to uncoated surfaces (Figure 5b). Figure 5c shows representative SEMs of HA/PA coated surfaces prior to and after immune cell surveillance experiments, providing further support for the statement that HA/PA coating on silicone surfaces prevents E. coli biofilm formation.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Together, these data show that neutrophil surveillance of silicone surface resulting in their death, makes the surface conducive for bacteria to form extensive biofilms. Hence, silicone surfaces need to be modified to not only prevent bacterial but also neutrophil adhesion. We demonstrate that a HA/PA coating reduces neutrophil death on the modified surface, which in turn results in lower bacterial biofilm formation on these surfaces. In summary, coating of silicone surfaces that reduces neutrophil and other immune cell death, is a promising approach to minimize biofilm formation on catheters.

ack.title: Acknowledgements
ack.p: This work was supported by a DBT-Wellcome India Alliance Intermediate fellowship to SJ (grant number IA/I/19/1/504265). SKJ is supported by a fellowship from the Department of Biotechnology, Government of India.

caption.title: Biofilm formation (E. coli) on surfaces following immune cell surveillance by THP-1 and HL-60 cells.
caption.p: Surfaces were exposed to phosphate buffered saline (PBS), complete media (CM) or cells in complete media (THP-1 or HL-60) for 2, 8 or 24 hours, followed by E. coli incubation for 48 hours, and then biofilm formation quantified or imaged. A - biofilm quantified using the crystal violet assay. B - representative scanning electron micrographs of biofilms (Scale bars - PBS, CM, HL-60 [10 μm]; bare silicone [100 μm]). Bare silicone surface is shown for reference. PS stands for polystyrene. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test was used for statistical comparison. Dotted line/dashed line in the graphs indicate crystal violet absorbance of bare polystyrene/silicone tube (background absorbance) respectively. *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001

caption.title: Biofilm formation (E. coli) on silicone surfaces following immune cell surveillance experiments with human blood cells.
caption.p: Surfaces were exposed to phosphate buffered saline (PBS), or complete media (CM), or polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNLs), or peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) or whole blood isolated from volunteer donors for 8 hours followed by incubation with E. coli for 48 hours. A - biofilm quantification using the crystal violet assay. Each dot represents cells from an individual donor. B - Representative scanning electron micrographs of E. coli biofilm on various surfaces (Scale bars - 10 μm). One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test was used for statistical comparison. Dotted line in the graph indicates crystal violet absorbance of bare silicone tube (background absorbance) *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001

caption.title: Biofilm formation (P. Aeruginosa) on silicone surfaces following immune cell surveillance experiments with HL-60 and human blood cells.
caption.p: Surfaces were exposed to phosphate buffered saline (PBS), or complete media (CM), or HL-60 cells, or polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMNLs), or peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) or whole blood isolated from volunteer donors for 8 hours followed by incubation with P. aeruginosa for 48 hours. A - biofilm quantification using the crystal violet assay. Each dot represents an independent experiment. B - Representative scanning electron micrographs of P. Aeruginosa biofilm (Scale bars - 10 μm). C - biofilm quantification using the crystal violet assay. Each dot represents cells from an individual donor. D - Representative scanning electron micrographs of P. Aeruginosa biofilm (Scale bars - 10 μm). One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test was used for statistical comparison. Dotted line/dashed line in the graphs indicate crystal violet absorbance of bare polystyrene/silicone tube (background absorbance) respectively. *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001

caption.title: Neutrophils die on silicone surface and this promotes biofilm formation.
caption.p: A - HL-60 cells were incubated in silicone coated PS tubes for 8 hours at 37 °C in a rotation condition. Cells in PS well plates (static condition) at 37 °C served as control. Cell percentages in different stages of apoptosis/necrosis based on Annexin V and PI staining. B - Biofilm quantified using crystal violet assay post lysed HL-60 incubation in silicone tubes. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test was used for statistical comparison. Dashed line in the graph B indicates crystal violet absorbance of bare silicone tube (background absorbance) *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001

caption.title: Biofilm formation (E. coli) on HA/PA coated surfaces following immune cell surveillance by HL-60 cells.
caption.p: Surfaces were exposed to phosphate buffered saline (PBS), complete media (CM) or cells in complete media (HL-60) for 8 hours followed by E. coli incubation for 48 hours, and then biofilm formation quantified or imaged. A - cell number in HA/PA coated tube with HL-60 cells. B - biofilm quantified using the crystal violet assay. Silicone_HL-60 is shown to provide a comparison with HA/PA coated surfaces (this specific dataset is same as that shown in figure 1A). C - representative scanning electron micrographs of biofilms (Scale bars -10 μm). Bare HA/PA coated silicone surface is shown for reference. One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s multiple comparisons test was used for statistical comparison. Dotted line in the graph indicates crystal violet absorbance of bare HA/PA coated silicone tube (background absorbance) *p<0.05, **p<0.01, ***p<0.001
